InstrumentName_nat: FR: Régime fiscal des voitures de sociétés NL: Belasting op bedrijfswagens
InstrumentDescription: To stimulate the employers to provide employees with low CO2 emission rate cars
Status_Revised_Details_1: The tax system is now based on CO2 emission rate and catalogue value of the car
Status_Revised_Details_2: From January 1, 2026, only zero-emission cars will benefit from advantageous tax treatment. A transition period for CO2-emitting vehicles is planned between 2023 and 2028
TF_PaymentUserDet: In theory, all companies can provide their employees with a company car. Given the high cost of this benefit in kind, it is concentrated in the upper deciles.
TF_CeilingDet: The flat-rate estimate of the employee's personal income tax benefit in kind is subject to a minimum amount (€1,540 for 2023 income). For the employer, a non-deductible amount for corporation tax is calculated on the basis of the amount owed by the employee for personal income tax and, consequently, the minimum amount applies to both PIT and CIT.

InstrumentDescription: Mandatory RPS through regulation 2006-58 under the Electricity Act. Eligible renewable energy sources shall be EcoLogoTM certified under the Environmental Choice Program. New Brunswick RPS does not include any penalty for non-compliance; however, if in any given year, the RPS target is not achieved, a generator has an additional period of maximum of 3 years to comply.
For non-compliance, Nova Scotia RPS stipulates a daily penalty of no more than CAD 500 000 to a maximum aggregate of CAD 10 million per occurrence.

PolicyDetails_1: The Clean Development Mechanism is a mechanism defined by the Kyoto protocol whereby projects with a component that induces the reduction or sequestration of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions are implemented

InstrumentName_en: Stimulation of sustainable energy production and climate transition (SDE++)
InstrumentDescription: Stimulation of sustainable energy production and climate transition (SDE++) is a subsidy for the production of renewable energy or applying CO2-reducing techniques in sectors such as industry, mobility, electricity, agriculture and the built environment. This, to ensure that the energy transition in the Netherlands remains feasible and affordable
ES_CeilingDet: Maximum SDE++ contribution (basic amount or application amount – basic energy price or basic greenhouse gas amount) * the number of full loads * the capacity * the duration in years.

InstrumentDescription: The energy innovation demonstration subsidy scheme (DEI) is expanded as much as possible from a scheme specifically for energy savings and renewable energy production to a scheme that supports all carbon emissions reduction options, in line with the scope of the Integrated Knowledge and Innovation Agenda (IKIA) that is established under the Climate Agreement. It will also emcompass options for system integration (incl. hydrogen) and for a more sustainable use of resources (circular economy)

InstrumentName_en: Subsidy schemes on energy efficiency and renewable energy in horticulture (EG)
InstrumentName_nat: EG Regeling investeringen in energie-efficiëntie glastuinbouw
InstrumentDescription: The EG scheme on energy efficiency and renewable energy in horticulture offers companies active in greenhouse cultivation a subsidy of 25% for specific measures (contained in an annually-revised list) for increasing energy efficiency (or generating or using renewable energy), for which the maximum subsidy can differ per investment. Clusters of companies can also apply for a subsidy. The EG scheme has various predecessor (EHG, IMM and IRE)

InstrumentName_en: Investment subsidies renewable energy systems and energy saving (ISDE)
InstrumentName_nat: ISDE Investeringssubsidie Duurzame Energie en energiebesparing
InstrumentDescription: To complement the SDE+ scheme with a scheme for smaller renewable energy systems, the investment subsidy scheme ISDE was started in 2016. This was also a follow up of agreements under the Energy Agreement and intends to contribute also to reduce gas consumption for heating. Initially households and small commercial users could apply for an allowance for the purchase of heat pumps, biomass boilers, solar water heaters, pellet stoves and small wood-fired boilers. From 2020 the scheme was (also for reasons of limiting NOx and other emissions to air) limited to heat pumps and solar water heaters, while in 2021 also subsidy possibilities for various types of (added) insulation measures were included for dwellings.

The Market Introduction for Energy Innovations (MEI) subsidy scheme is intended for investments in the horticultural sector towards innovative energy systems for greenhouses that reduce CO2 emissions and primary energy consumption. Investments in energy efficient innovative greenhouses can also be subsidised. In this respect there are specific requirements contained in the scheme. They must be innovative energy systems or innovative greenhouses that have only just been introduced. Depending on the type of investment, the subsidy amounts to 30% or 40% of the investment .
Tax on the use of electricity and natural gas
Status_Revised_Details_1: The tax rates were adjusted for inflation.

PolicyDetails_1: This subsidy increases over time whereas an exemption in the regulatory energy tax is being phased out.

TF_RCM_Criteria_2: Product or Activity - A tax refund for the use of electricity above 10 000 000 kWh per year per connection to the electricity grid as long as the average rate per kWh is above the European minimum rate for electricity for business use.

Funds of up to GBP 400 million were earmarked for the period 2008/09 to 2010/11 for the Environmental Transformation Fund. The ETF aimed to encourage the development of low-carbon energy and energy efficiency technologies in the UK, speeding up their commercial use and reducing overall demand.

The scheme aimed to encourage the replacement of old G‐rated boilers with newer A‐rated energy efficient boilers, with the aim of creating business for installers and boiler manufacturers, creating savings on energy bills for households, and reducing carbon dioxide emissions.

InstrumentDescription: The Universal Home Insulation Scheme (UHIS) was introduced in 2010-11, replacing the Home Insulation Scheme (HIS). UHIS is a free-to-all scheme which provides free energy efficiency measures, such as loft and cavity wall insulation in selected areas.
This was a GBP 1 million fund aimed a communities and housing providers that focused on energy efficiency in hard to treat housing.
Status_EndedDiscontinued_Details: After the second round of funding, the money allocated to the fund had been exhausted.

InstrumentDescription: The CESP requires gas and electricity suppliers and electricity generators to deliver energy saving measures to domestic consumers in specific low income areas of Great Britain. It is intended to be a "whole house" approach that increases energy efficiency and reduces fuel bills and CO2 emissions.
Auth_Admin_National_Name: Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Energy

InstrumentDescription: The GBP 12 million Boiler Replacement Scheme aims to assist low-income households replace old, inefficient boilers with new, more efficient and cleaner ones, with the objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and tackling fuel poverty.

A levy imposed on electricity suppliers who passed it on to their consumers. Used to finance compliance with the Non-fossil fuel obligation (NFFO) to incorporate a larger proportion of renewables in electricity production.
Auth_Admin_National_Details: Office of Electricity Regulation, which is now Office for Gas and Electricity Markets
TF_PaymentUserDet: Duty is due from the manufacturer for home produced diesel delivered to home use, and from the importer for imported diesel. Levy passed onto the customers of the electricity suppliers to make up for the costs of the NFFO
EarmarkPurpose_1: Support for electricity generation from renewable sources under Non Fossil Fuel Obligation (NFFO) arrangements.

InstrumentDescription: An environmental tax on UK business energy use, charged at the time of supply. Charged by the business energy suppliers/ producers who supply the taxable commodities. The taxable commodities are for heating, lighting and power purpose (such as natural gas, electricity, petroleum, coal).The aid/relief given under CCL is the amount of reduction given from the full rate of tax. CCL is collected on HMRC’s behalf by energy suppliers from customers.Climate Change Levy is paid at either, or both the: 1) Main levy rate and 2) Carbon Price Support rate.Business energy suppliers are responsible for charging the correct levy to customers, while an electricity generator is responsible for accounting and charging the correct Carbon Price Support rate.
Status_Revised_Details_1: Tax rates were increased in line with the expected rate of inflation for 2013/14. The Carbon Price Floor (CPF) came into effect on 1 April 2013. CPF is a tax on fossil fuels used in the generation of electricity, achieved through changes to the existing CCL regime in the case of gas, solid fuels and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) used in electricity generation.
Status_Revised_Details_2: Legislation introduced in the Finance Bill 2021 to amend the CCL main rates and reduced rates (Paragraph 42 of Schedule 6 of the Finance Act 2000, following Budget 2020 proposed rate changes.
Status_Revised_Details_3: At Spring Budget 2023 legislative changes (via Spring Finance Bill 2023) were introduced to increase the main rate of CCL for gas to meet the frozen electricity rate of £0.00775 per kWh, taking effect from 1 April 2024. The main rate of CCL on LPG (£0.02175 per kg) would continue to be frozen in 2024-25.
Auth_Admin_National_Details: HM Revenue & Customs
TF_PaymentUserDet: The person/company causing certain emissions. The importer/wholesale provider of a product. Energy producers/suppliers who charge CCL on their taxable supplies to businesses.
PolicyDetails_1: The CCAs are linked to the Climate Change Levy, a tax on certain energy use by the UK non-domestic sector (industry, commerce, agriculture and the public sector). The levy applies to electricity, coal, gas and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG).
TF_RCM_Criteria_1: Eligibility to make a tax credit claim if overpaid CCL or underclaimed relief entitlement.

InstrumentDescription: A mandatory carbon emissions reduction scheme in the United Kingdom which applied to large energy-intensive organisations in the public and private sector. Designed to improve energy efficiency and cut carbon dioxide emissions using allowances. Energy intensive organisations that met the qualification criteria were required to participate, and had to buy allowances for every tonne of carbon they emitted.
Status_EndedReplaced_Details: Associated with an increase in Climate Change Levy to streamline business energy tax, as part of the Streamlined Energy and Carbon Reporting (SECR), introduced in 2019
Auth_Admin_National_Name: Environment Agency, Scottish Environment Protection Agency, Northern Ireland Environment Agency, Natural Resources Wales
Auth_Admin_National_Details: These are arms-length environmental government bodies for each of England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales
TF_PaymentUserDet: Energy intensive organisations for energy not already covered under climate change agreements and the EU Emissions Trading Scheme. Some public bodies - "mandated participants", including all UK central government departments and devolved administrations.
TF_PaymentRecipientName: Environment Agency, Scottish Environment Protection Agency, Northern Ireland Environment Agency, Natural Resources Wales
TF_CeilingDet: Qualification assessed at the group level (entire organisational structure): 1. Having at least one settled half hourly electricity meter (sHHM) 2. Using 6,000 megawatt hours or more of qualifying electricity supplied through SHHMs
TF_RCM_Name_1: CRC repayment mechanism for surplus allowances
TF_RCM_Criteria_1: For participants who have surrendered more allowances than required (surplus allowances) may make a request for the repayment of the balance, if: 1. A participant has surrendered allowances commensurate for their reported emissions, but a reporting error has resulted in surplus allowances 2. An organisation has registered for participant in the CRC Scheme in error and subsequently surrendered allowances
TF_RCM_Beneficiaries_Details_1: Organisations who made an error in reporting resulting in surplus allowances

InstrumentName_en: Carbon Reduction Commitment Energy Efficiency Scheme
InstrumentName_nat: Carbon Reduction Commitment Energy Efficiency Scheme
InstrumentDescription: The CRC is a mandatory scheme aimed at improving energy efficiency and cutting emissions in large public and private sector organisations that do not fall under the EU ETS. The scheme features a range of reputational, behavioural and financial drivers.
Status_Revised_Details_1: Reviewed in 2011 to simplify the scheme. Key changes are a reduction in the number of fuels covered by the scheme, prices of allowances to remain fixed (instead of auctioning), reduction of overlap with the CCA and EU ETS, and simplified organisational rules and qualification process. Changes will come into force in April 2013.
TP_PermitUser_Details: Large retail organisations and public sector organisations that are not covered by the EU ETS nor the CCA, who used more than 6000mWh of electricity in 2008 and who have at least one half-hourly meter installed
TP_AllocationDet: Allowances are allocated, but they are not free - they are sold for a fixed price of 12 GBP each.
TP_MonitoringDet: The authority can request a compliance notice and/or inspect the premises (with prior notice)
TP_SanctionsDet: Both civil and criminal penalities for non-compliance apply

InstrumentDescription: To encourage UK energy intensive sectors to increase energy efficiency, and thereby reduce CO2 emissions, as a part of the overall UK Climate Change Programme.
Status_Revised_Details_1: The second CCA scheme began in April 2013 and a revision to legislation was made on 30 December 2016 to increase buyout price for Target Period 3 and 4, further details on https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/climate-change-agreements-discussion-paper-on-the-target-review-2016-and-buy-out-price-review. An extension to the scheme was introduced in 2020 to add a fifth target period starting 1 Jan 2020 to 31 Dec 2021 and reduced rates of CCL through to 31 March 2025. A consultation on this extension can be found here: https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/climate-change-agreements-scheme-extension-and-reforms-for-any-future-scheme
Auth_Adopt_Details: UK Government, via HM Treasury (finance ministry) and DECC
Auth_Admin_National_Details: HM Treasury, with input from DECC and other relevant UK Government Departments, including HM Revenue and Customs and The Department of Energy and Climate Change.
VA_TermsDet: Targets can be found in sector level agreements, Targets can be found in the sector level agreements, Targets can be found in the sector level agreements (, Targets can be found in the sector level agreements ("Unbrella Agreements"). These can be viewed in the Umbrella Agreements section of the Defra CCA web-site. and Targets can be found in the sector level agreements.
VA_BindingDet: The agreements sound in administrative law not contract law. Consequently any decision by the Secretary of State can be challenged and subjected to judicial review.
VA_MonitoringDet: Defra undertakes auditing by spot checks on participants' data collection and management systems. There is follow-up action as appropriate. Similar auditing occurs at sector level.
VA_SanctionsDet: Non-compliance with targets will result in participants losing their entitlement to 80% discount from the CCL for a minimum two year period. Participants will be able to obtain discount once again if they have caught up with their targets after this time.
PolicyDetails_1: The CCAs are linked to the Climate Change Levy, a tax on certain energy use by the UK non-domestic sector (industry, commerce, agriculture and the public sector). The levy applies to electricity, coal, gas and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG)
PolicyDetails_2: The CCAs are linked to the UK Emissions Trading Scheme (UKETS). CCA participants can purchase carbon allowances to help meet targets. If participants exceed targets then they can trade their surplus following independent verification
PolicyDetails_3: Climate change agreements are voluntary agreements made between UK industry and the Environment Agency to reduce energy use and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. In return, operators receive a discount on the Climate Change Levy (CCL), a tax added to electricity and fuel bills. The Environment Agency administers the CCA scheme on behalf of the whole of the UK.
Reference_Details_1: The National Audit Office, NAO, reviewed the Climate change Agreements and Climate Change Levy in 2007 for the Environmental Audit Committee of the UK Parliament. The review was published on 30 August 2007
Reference_Details_2: Climate change agreements are voluntary agreements made between UK industry and the Environment Agency to reduce energy use and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. In return, operators receive a discount on the Climate Change Levy (CCL), a tax added to electricity and fuel bills. The Environment Agency administers the CCA scheme on behalf of the whole of the UK.CCAs are available for a wide range of industry sectors from major energy-intensive processes such as chemicals and paper to supermarkets and agricultural businesses such as intensive pig and poultry farming. There are 2 types of CCA – umbrella agreements and underlying agreements. The Department of Energy and Climate Change and industry sectors negotiated energy efficiency targets for each sector – the sector commitment. The targets were then included in umbrella agreements held between sector associations and the Environment Agency. Umbrella agreements also list the processes that are eligible for a CCA. In 2020 BEIS negotiated new targets for 2021 and 2022.
Reference_Details_3: CCA scheme extended until March 2025 The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) has extended the CCA scheme for 2 years, until March 2025. For details, see BEIS’s consultation response(https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/climate-change-agreements-scheme-extension-and-reforms-for-any-future-scheme). The Environment Agency has updated the CCA operations manual (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/climate-change-agreements-operations-manual--2) to include guidance about the extension of the scheme.

InstrumentDescription: The Tax Code provides credits of varying amounts for the production within the United States and sale of specified eligible components, including specified solar energy components, wind energy components, inverters, qualifying battery components, and applicable critical minerals. The production of an eligible component is only eligible for a credit if sold after 2022. For all eligible components other than applicable critical minerals, the credit is phased out from 2030 to 2032, with components other than critical minerals no longer receiving any credit if sold after 2032.

Utilities may purchase, sell, or trade Clean Energy Credits, which are defined as 1 MWh of clean energy (as defined above) or 3,412,000 BTUs. Any excess amounts of clean energy supplied during a specific goal period or any Clean Energy Credits purchased from another supplier may be counted toward the next goal period. Other than this exception all clean energy sources must be in service, purchased or contracted for by the effective dates of the CPS program goals.
